meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I can talk briefly about MR spectroscopy, which I'm guessing most of you are familiar with, but it it is a marker of um or it is a method that can measure, you know, quantitative metabolite concentrations localized in whatever region. meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Bogyo - Stanford
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's also sampling error, right? I mean because you have to know where you want to look, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I mean we can do whole brain, you can do multiple regions. I guess um yeah, I mean in a clinical setting you would do a small region of interest. Um so you'd have some information already. Um but I guess in terms of the bigger question of metabolism, you know, um something that is kind of emerging is genetic counseling. So using, you know, gene mutations to predict disease.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I guess the idea that I had with metabolic imaging is really, you know, we're not looking at kind of metabolism reprogramming, which we know is really common in cancer, but it's actually probably related to a number of different diseases, diabetes like Ping was saying. meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Cancer, do some genetics tests. Um children do some sort of genetic screening, etc, etc. But metabolism is often left out and we know like the prompt is saying, we know that metabolic changes can actually proceed any physiological or structural changes. So from a very big picture, imaging metabolism with maybe in the clinic with the exception of FDG pet and some other tracers from mostly cancer, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um is is pretty absent. And so I think there is a big need for thinking about this on a very large scale in terms of, you know, why is metabolism important? Is it important? How is it important? Um and obviously with something like MRI we're working on a very macroscopic scale like you said, we have large regions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: So is MRI done like pretty routinely now like for for metabolic imaging in cancer?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like I mean it does it does seem like it requires a lot of time and instrumentation and cost and other things. I mean are there barriers there?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I mean it it I would say in many clinics it is done routinely. Um it it depends a little on the tumor, but it's the exact same instrumentation and anytime someone has a tumor you would scan them with an MRI anyway. So they're already in the scanner if you allow if your site does spectroscopy,

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
meeting_annotations.transcript: it's it's naturally integrated into every MRI whether you use it or not. You you kind of have to pay extra for it when you're buying your system. So if you didn't do that you won't have it. But um even non-academic sites are using spectroscopy for tumors. Um so I wouldn't say it's routine, but I would say for so for example for fatty liver disease it is routine because that's a really great way to quickly sample fat distribution.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Candace Fleischer (Emory, she/her)
